overview.title: CrowdStrike Query Language (CQL)
overview.description: CQL is the query language for CrowdStrike Falcon platform, enabling threat hunting and investigation across endpoint telemetry

sections.title: Introduction to CQL
sections.content: CQL provides a powerful query interface for searching and analyzing security events in CrowdStrike Falcon. It supports filtering, projection, aggregation, and time-based queries across multiple data sources.

sections.title: Query Syntax
sections.content: CQL queries consist of filters, operators, and optional pipeline operations. Basic syntax: field_name operator 'value'. Multiple conditions can be combined with AND/OR. Pipeline operators (|) enable chaining operations like select, limit, stats.

sections.title: Available Fields
sections.content: CQL provides access to numerous telemetry fields including process information (process_name, command_line, pid), network data (source_ip, destination_ip, port), file operations (file_path, file_hash), and more. Field names are case-sensitive.

sections.title: Comparison Operators
sections.content: CQL supports equality (=, !=), comparison (>, >=, <, <=), string operators (contains, startswith, endswith), list operators (IN, NOT IN), pattern matching (=~, !~), and existence checks (EXISTS, NOT EXISTS).

sections.title: Time-based Filtering
sections.content: Use @timestamp field for time filtering. Supports absolute timestamps and relative time (now() - 24h, now() - 7d). Always include time bounds for optimal performance.

sections.title: Aggregation and Statistics
sections.content: Use stats operator for aggregation: | stats count, sum, avg, min, max by field_list. Supports grouping and having clauses for advanced analytics.

sections.title: Field Projection
sections.content: Use | select field1, field2 to limit returned fields. Improves performance by reducing data transfer. Can include calculated fields and aliases.

sections.title: Query Best Practices
sections.content: Always include time bounds, use indexed fields for filtering, limit result sets, avoid leading wildcards, use specific patterns over broad regex, quote string values properly.

sections.title: Threat Hunting
sections.content: CQL enables proactive threat hunting through flexible queries across process execution, network activity, file operations, registry changes, and authentication events. Combine multiple indicators for high-fidelity detections.

sections.title: Process Events
sections.content: Query process creation, termination, and modification events. Key fields: process_name, command_line, parent_process_name, user_name, pid, ppid. Useful for detecting suspicious process execution patterns.

sections.title: Network Events
sections.content: Query network connections, DNS queries, and HTTP requests. Key fields: source_ip, destination_ip, destination_port, protocol, http_user_agent. Useful for C2 detection and lateral movement.

sections.title: File Events
sections.content: Query file creation, modification, deletion, and hash events. Key fields: file_path, file_name, file_hash, event_type. Useful for malware staging and data exfiltration detection.

sections.title: Registry Events
sections.content: Query Windows registry modifications. Key fields: registry_key, registry_value, event_type. Useful for persistence mechanism detection and system configuration changes.

sections.title: Authentication Events
sections.content: Query login, logoff, and authentication events. Key fields: user_name, source_ip, status, event_type. Useful for detecting brute force attacks and suspicious account activity.

sections.title: Query Examples
sections.content: Common hunting queries include: PowerShell with encoded commands, suspicious parent-child process relationships, outbound connections to high ports, executable files in temp directories, autorun registry modifications.
